Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: DNA Analysis As A Tool For Understanding Population Movement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research on migration in Archaeology has largely focused on its role as an agent of cultural change. However, migration and genetic admixture are also drivers of biological change and adaptation. Consequently, characterizing how ancient migrations shape genetic diversity is vital to inform understanding of biological ancestry, cultural evolution, and health outcomes in admixed human populations. But, because modern populations do not retain all the genomic diversity of ancient groups, genetic research with contemporary individuals provides limited resolution for reconstructing ancient demographic events. This limitation can be addressed by combining archaeological questions with ancient DNA. This investigation characterizes the genetic diversity of ancient human groups and test hypotheses about their relationships to other ancient and modern populations. Specifically, ancient DNA obtained from human skeletal remains in three archaeological sites (Tibes, Punta Candelero and Paso del Indio) will be analyzed to investigate the role of migration and genetic admixture in the history of pre-Columbian populations from the Caribbean island of Puerto Rico. The project incorporates training of undergraduate students in laboratory and analytical methods and contributes to the participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences through training of a female, Puerto Rican doctoral student. The researchers will engage the public by disseminating project findings through Ask-A Biologist, an online resource for students, teachers and the public, and by collaborating with archaeologists and the Ceremonial Center of Tibes site museum to integrate findings in public site tours. A significant aspect of this research is the optimization of protocols for DNA recovery from degraded skeletal remains. This methodological development improves ancient DNA recovery from remains in tropical environments, and can be extended to forensic applications where DNA may be damaged due to corpse deposition in adverse preservation contexts.

Debate remains about how many migrants settled the island of Puerto Rico in antiquity, where they came from, and how these processes influenced social interaction networks across the ancient Caribbean basin. This investigation compares ancient mitochondrial and nuclear DNA from skeletal remains dated A.D. 500-1300, with data from other modern and ancient indigenous populations of the Americas to determine: (1) How were ancient populations in Puerto Rico related to continental Native American groups, and what may this indicate about their origins? (2) What was the extent of gene flow in the pre-contact Caribbean, and what may this indicate about local social interaction? Project findings reassess existing models for the peopling of Puerto Rico and the Caribbean, and explore how migration and admixture shaped the biocultural diversity of ancient Caribbean populations. By also examining the extent of inter-island migration and genetic exchange, this investigation elucidates the role of kinship, residence patterns and mobility in the maintenance of interaction networks across the pre-Columbian Caribbean. Lastly, this study also sheds light on the genetic relationships between pre-Columbian populations and modern Puerto Ricans, the second largest Hispanic group in the USA. Given the growing role that Native American ethnicity plays in contemporary Puerto Rican culture, project results have implications for the construction and experience of modern Puerto Rican identity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previous archaeological research indicates that Native American groups occupied Puerto Rico for approximately 4,000 years before present, until European colonization in 1493. Many researchers agree that there was constant human movement into Puerto Rico and other islands during the pre-contact period. But the source of these populations, the number of migratory waves, and the extent and role of genetic admixture in this process remain disputed. At a more regional scale, there is broad agreement that ancient indigenous communities from Puerto Rico engaged in continuous interaction with other island groups. But, disentangling the precise nature and mechanisms for this interaction remains elusive. To inform these issues, this study sampled 132 human skeletal remains excavated from three archaeological sites in Puerto Rico, all dated between A.D. 500-1300: Tibes, Paso del Indio and Punta Candelero. Using enrichment and next-generation sequencing techniques, we reconstructed the complete mitochondrial (mtDNA) genome from 45 of these individuals. MtDNA is passed on directly from mothers to offspring without recombination. Thus, by characterizing mtDNA lineages we can ascertain maternal ancestry and trace the continental origins of human populations.

  We found that the ancient peoples of Puerto Rico carried high frequencies of two mtDNA lineages, A and C. This as well as the specific lineages represented suggests a South American origin for these populations, which is consistent with archaeological evidence. But we cannot exclude the possibility that people from other American regions may have also arrived into Puerto Rico in antiquity. When we compared the mtDNA data obtained from pre-contact Puerto Rico with data from other ancient Caribbean populations, we found that few mtDNA lineages were shared between island groups. This suggests that female-mediated gene flow was not essential to maintain inter-island social networks. Lastly, we found three mtDNA lineages that were shared exclusively between the pre-contact population and modern Puerto Ricans. This suggests there is some genetic continuity between the two despite the large demographic shifts that occurred with European colonization. 

  Findings from this project contribute to a more complete reconstruction of pre-contact population history in the Caribbean and increase understanding of how ancient migration and admixture has shaped the biological and cultural diversity of modern Puerto Ricans. These data impact the field of Caribbean Archaeology by challenging existing views and posing new scenarios for archaeological reconstruction. Additionally, by exploring the links between ancient and modern peoples, this research has implications for understanding the genetic diversity and cultural identity of Puerto Ricans, who are the second largest Hispanic group in the USA. 

  An additional part of this work was the development and optimization of a new extraction method for recovering ancient DNA from skeletal remains excavated from tropical environments. We compared the performance of this method to existing protocols and tested it on a subset of the remains from this study.  This extraction method can also be extended to forensics applications, where surviving DNA is often extremely degraded. Results of this part of the study were published in a peer-reviewed article in the American Journal of Physical Anthropology (Nieves-Colón et al. 2018).

The data collection and analyses involved in this study led to the completion of the doctoral degree of the co-PI, who is a female researcher from Puerto Rico, and resulted in training of several graduate and undergraduate students in ancient DNA laboratory methods. Overall research results are currently being prepared for peer-review and the data generated will be made publicly available upon publication. Additionally, the project has been presented at several scientific meetings, and coordination of public outreach efforts in Puerto Rico and the USA is currently underway.
